# List of _Dragon Ball_ films

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/29/DragonBoxMovies.jpg/220px-
DragonBoxMovies.jpg)](/wiki/File:DragonBoxMovies.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:DragonBoxMovies.jpg "Enlarge")

_Dragon Box: The Movies_ , a DVD box set that includes the first seventeen
theatrical films, released by Toei on April 14, 2006.

Since the debut of the [anime](/wiki/Anime "Anime") adaptation of [Akira
Toriyama](/wiki/Akira_Toriyama "Akira Toriyama")'s [_Dragon Ball_
manga](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_\(manga\) "Dragon Ball \(manga\)") in 1986, [Toei
Animation](/wiki/Toei_Animation "Toei Animation") has produced twenty
[theatrical](/wiki/Movie_theater "Movie theater") [films](/wiki/Film "Film")
based on the franchise: four based on the original [_Dragon Ball_
anime](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_\(anime\) "Dragon Ball \(anime\)"), fifteen based on
the sequel series _[Dragon Ball Z](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_Z "Dragon Ball Z")_ and
one upcoming film based on the _[Dragon Ball Super](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_Super
"Dragon Ball Super")_ series.

The first seventeen films were originally shown as back-to-back presentations
alongside other Toei film productions and thus have a running time below
[feature length](/wiki/Feature_length "Feature length") (around 45–60 minutes
each), the sole exception being 1996's _[The Path to
Power](/wiki/Dragon_Ball:_The_Path_to_Power "Dragon Ball: The Path to Power")_
(which has a running time of 80 minutes). The first through fifth films were
shown at the Toei Manga Festival
([東映まんがまつり](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%9D%B1%E6%98%A0%E3%81%BE%E3%82%93%E3%81%8C%E3%81%BE%E3%81%A4%E3%82%8A
"ja:東映まんがまつり"), _Tōei Manga Matsuri_), while the sixth through seventeenth
films were shown at the Toei Anime Fair
([東映アニメフェア](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%9D%B1%E6%98%A0%E3%82%A2%E3%83%8B%E3%83%A1%E3%83%95%E3%82%A7%E3%82%A2
"ja:東映アニメフェア"), _Toei Anime Fea_). These films were mostly alternate re-
tellings of certain story arcs involving new characters or extra side-stories
that do not correlate with the same [continuity](/wiki/Continuity_\(fiction\)
"Continuity \(fiction\)") as the manga or TV series.

The newest films in the series, _[Battle of
Gods](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_Z:_Battle_of_Gods "Dragon Ball Z: Battle of Gods")_ ,
_[Resurrection'F'](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_Z:_Resurrection_%27F%27 "Dragon Ball Z:
Resurrection 'F'")_ and _[Broly](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_Super:_Broly "Dragon Ball
Super: Broly")_ , differ from the earlier ones, as they are full-length
feature films set between chapters 517 and 518 of the manga, with Toriyama
deeply involved in their creation.[1][2] Toriyama did have some involvement
with the earlier films, such as checking the scripts, altering new characters
and their names or designing them from the ground up himself.[3]

There are also three [television specials](/wiki/Television_special
"Television special") that were broadcast on [Fuji TV](/wiki/Fuji_TV "Fuji
TV") and two [short films](/wiki/Short_film "Short film"), which were shown at
the 2008 Jump Super Anime Tour and Jump Festa 2012 respectively. A two-part
hour-long crossover TV special between _Dragon Ball Z_ , _[One
Piece](/wiki/One_Piece "One Piece")_ and _[Toriko](/wiki/Toriko "Toriko")_
aired on Fuji TV in 2013. Additionally, there is a two-part [original video
animation](/wiki/Original_video_animation "Original video animation") created
as strategy guides for the 1993 video game _[Dragon Ball Z Side Story: Plan to
Eradicate the
Saiyans](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_Z_Side_Story:_Plan_to_Eradicate_the_Saiyans "Dragon
Ball Z Side Story: Plan to Eradicate the Saiyans")_ , which was remade in 2010
and included with the _[Raging Blast 2](/wiki/Dragon_Ball:_Raging_Blast_2
"Dragon Ball: Raging Blast 2")_ video game.

As with the franchise's anime television series, the first nineteen films and
the first three TV specials were licensed in North America by
[Funimation](/wiki/Funimation "Funimation"). _Dragon Ball Z_ movies six and
twelve received select theatrical presentations in the United States, as part
of a double-feature on March 17, 2006, while movies fourteen and fifteen were
given limited theatrical runs in August 2014 and August 2015 respectively. In
Europe, [AB Groupe](/wiki/AB_Groupe "AB Groupe") licensed the second and third
_Dragon Ball_ movies, the first nine _Z_ movies and the first two TV specials.

## Television
specials[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Dragon_Ball_films&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Television specials")]

The _Dragon Ball_ franchise has spawned three one-hour long [television
specials](/wiki/Television_special "Television special") that aired on [Fuji
TV](/wiki/Fuji_TV "Fuji TV"), the first two based on the "Z" portion of the
series and the third based on the "GT" portion. Of these specials, the first
and third are original stories created by the anime staff, while the second is
based on a special chapter of the manga.

Though the specials aired on TV in Japan, Funimation's North American releases
of the episodes are on home video, each one labeled "Feature" the same as
their theatrical films. This, doubled with the inclusion of the "Z" specials
in Funimation's remastered "Movie Double Features" has caused fans to continue
to erroneously believe these to be theatrical films, when they are not.

On April 7, 2013, a two-part hour-long crossover TV special, between _Dragon
Ball Z_ , _[One Piece](/wiki/One_Piece "One Piece")_ and
_[Toriko](/wiki/Toriko "Toriko")_ , referred to as _Dream 9 Toriko & One Piece
& Dragon Ball Z Super Collaboration Special!!_ aired on Fuji TV.[6] The first
part is named "Run, Strongest Team! Toriko, Luffy, Goku!" (走れ最強軍団！トリコとルフィと悟空！,
_Hashire Saikyō Gundan! Toriko to Luffy to Goku!_) and the second is titled
"History's Strongest Collaboration vs. Glutton of the Sea" (史上最強コラボVS海の大食漢,
_Shijō Saikyō Collaboration vs. Umi no Taishokukan_).[6] The plot has the
International Gourmet Organization (from _Toriko_) sponsoring the Tenka'ichi
Shokuōkai, a race with no rules that characters from all three series compete
in.[7]

On October 8, 2017, a two-part TV special of _[Dragon Ball
Super](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_Super "Dragon Ball Super")_ aired on Fuji TV. It
counted as both episodes 109 and 110 of the series.

## Festival
shorts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Dragon_Ball_films&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Festival shorts")]

_Dragon Ball: Yo! Son Goku and His Friends Return!!_ is a 35-minute [short
film](/wiki/Short_film "Short film") that was shown at the 2008 Jump Super
Anime Tour, which visited ten Japanese cities to celebrate _[Weekly Shōnen
Jump](/wiki/Weekly_Sh%C5%8Dnen_Jump "Weekly Shōnen Jump")_ 's 40th
anniversary.[8] It was later released as a triple feature DVD with _[One
Piece: Romance Dawn Story](/wiki/One_Piece#Original_video_animations "One
Piece")_ and _[Tegami Bachi: Light and Blue Night
Fantasy](/wiki/Tegami_Bachi#Anime "Tegami Bachi")_ in 2009, that was available
only through a mail-in offer exclusive to Japanese residents.[9] In 2013, it
was included in the limited edition home video release of _[Battle of
Gods](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_Z:_Battle_of_Gods "Dragon Ball Z: Battle of Gods")_.

Another short film, _Dragon Ball: Episode of Bardock_ , was shown at the [Jump
Festa](/wiki/Jump_Festa "Jump Festa") 2012 event on December 17, 2011.[10] It
is an adaptation of the three part spin-off manga of the same name by Naho
Ōishi that ran in _[V Jump](/wiki/V_Jump "V Jump")_ from August to October
2011, which is a spin-off sequel to the _[Bardock – The Father of
Goku](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_Z:_Bardock_%E2%80%93_The_Father_of_Goku "Dragon Ball
Z: Bardock – The Father of Goku")_ TV special.[11] It was later released on
DVD in the February 3, 2012 issue of _[Saikyō Jump](/wiki/Saiky%C5%8D_Jump
"Saikyō Jump")_ together with _[Dragon Ball: Plan to Eradicate the Super
Saiyans](/wiki/Dragon_Ball:_Plan_to_Eradicate_the_Super_Saiyans "Dragon Ball:
Plan to Eradicate the Super Saiyans")_.[12] The film was included subtitled in
the European and North American exclusive [Xbox 360](/wiki/Xbox_360 "Xbox
360") video game _[Dragon Ball Z: For Kinect](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_Z:_For_Kinect
"Dragon Ball Z: For Kinect")_ , released in October 2012.[13]

## Original video
animations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Dragon_Ball_films&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Original video animations")]

In 1993, Toei Animation, in cooperation with _[Weekly Shōnen
Jump](/wiki/Weekly_Sh%C5%8Dnen_Jump "Weekly Shōnen Jump")_ and _[V
Jump](/wiki/V_Jump "V Jump")_ , produced a two-part [original video
animation](/wiki/Original_video_animation "Original video animation") (OVA)
that serves as a video [strategy guide](/wiki/Strategy_guide "Strategy guide")
to the [Family Computer](/wiki/Nintendo_Entertainment_System "Nintendo
Entertainment System") game titled _[Dragon Ball Z Side Story: Plan to
Eradicate the
Saiyans](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_Z_Side_Story:_Plan_to_Eradicate_the_Saiyans "Dragon
Ball Z Side Story: Plan to Eradicate the Saiyans")_.[14] The first volume was
released on [VHS](/wiki/VHS "VHS") on July 23, while the second was released
on August 25. The animation was also used in the 1994 two part video games,
_True Plan to Eradicate the Saiyans_ , released for the
[Playdia](/wiki/Playdia "Playdia"). The complete OVA was included in the
second _Dragon Ball Z Dragon Box_ DVD set released in Japan in 2003.

The OVA was remade for the 2010 [PlayStation 3](/wiki/PlayStation_3
"PlayStation 3") and [Xbox 360](/wiki/Xbox_360 "Xbox 360") video game _[Dragon
Ball: Raging Blast 2](/wiki/Dragon_Ball:_Raging_Blast_2 "Dragon Ball: Raging
Blast 2")_ under the title _[Dragon Ball: Plan to Eradicate the Super
Saiyans](/wiki/Dragon_Ball:_Plan_to_Eradicate_the_Super_Saiyans "Dragon Ball:
Plan to Eradicate the Super Saiyans")_.[14] It was included in _Dragon Ball:
Raging Blast 2_ as a bonus feature, unlocked at the start of gameplay without
any necessary cheat code or in-game achievement, presented in its original
Japanese-language audio with subtitles appropriate for each region. It was
later released on DVD in the February 3, 2012 issue of _Saikyō Jump_ together
with _[Dragon Ball: Episode of Bardock](/wiki/Dragon_Ball:_Episode_of_Bardock
"Dragon Ball: Episode of Bardock")_.[12]

Japanese title | English title | Japanese release | North American release   
---|---|---|---  
_Gaiden: Saiya-jin Zetsumetsu Keikaku_ (外伝 サイヤ人絶滅計画) | _[Side Story: Plan to Eradicate the Saiyans](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_Z_Side_Story:_Plan_to_Eradicate_the_Saiyans "Dragon Ball Z Side Story: Plan to Eradicate the Saiyans")_ | August 6, 1993 (1993-08-06) | －   
_Sūpā Saiya-jin Zetsumetsu Keikaku_ (超サイヤ人絶滅計画) | _[Plan to Eradicate the Super Saiyans](/wiki/Dragon_Ball:_Plan_to_Eradicate_the_Super_Saiyans "Dragon Ball: Plan to Eradicate the Super Saiyans")_ | November 11, 2010 (2010-11-11) | November 2, 2010 (2010-11-02)  
  
## Educational
programs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Dragon_Ball_films&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Educational programs")]

Two educational shorts based on the original _Dragon Ball_ anime were produced
in 1988. The first was a [traffic safety](/wiki/Traffic_safety "Traffic
safety") special titled _Goku 's Traffic Safety_ (悟空の交通安全, _Gokū no Kōtsū
Ansen_), while the second was a [fire safety](/wiki/Fire_safety "Fire safety")
special titled _Goku 's Fire Brigade_ (悟空の消防隊, _Gokū no Shōbōtai_). The two
educational films were included in the _Dragon Box_ DVD set released in Japan
in 2004.
